Certainly Princess Mononoke is among my favorite films and along with Spirited Away are my favorites at Studio Ghibli.

Those who have not yet watched, give an opportunity to watch this marvel of animation !!

title: A Dark Masterpiece
review: In many of it's other films, Studio Ghibli has excelled in telling small, thoughtful, and personal stories. Amongst such films as "Kiki's Delivery Service" and "Whisper of the Heart", "Princess Mononoke" is an anomaly. It is an intense, dark story about total, irredeemable war between a group of careless humans and the bloodthirsty protectors and armies of nature. The animation is breathtaking, the score is fantastic, the characters are complex, and the story is intriguing. Both sides are treated with nuance, avoiding the crappy, dim-witted one-sidedness of films such as James Cameron's "Avatar". Indeed, this serves to raise the stakes as both sides wage a bitter war. Additionally, the true protagonist of the story, Ashitaka, is one of Studio Ghibli's finest leads, tirelessly working to stop the needless bloodshed as the story rushes towards it's shocking climax. While the dark themes, gore, and minor language may be a turn off for many fans of Ghibli's usual fare, "Princess Mononoke" is a unique, dark masterpiece.

title: A marvel in animation and cinema
review:
Everytime I watch this film and it ends, I get the feeling that something amazing has just happened. That being said Princess Mononoke is one of the best films I've ever seen. It's a film that get better everytime I watch it and one that I will always hold in high regard.

The follows an incredibly selfless and shockingly beautiful young prince named Ashitaka who kills a demonic boar when it attacks his village but not without consequences. The demon curses him which forces him to leave his village to find a cure and he comes across a war between humans and nature.

The film does have an environmental message but I always thought that wasn't the main message about the film, I'll get to that later. First things first, the animation is phenomenal. One of the best looking movies I've ever seen, everything looks flawless. This movie has been out for at least 22 years now and the fact that it looks better than most newer movies is quite something. It's boosted by an incredible amount of color, atmosphere and smoothness that feels organic and makes the world feel alive.

The music is also fantastic as it summarizes exactly what the film is: an animated epic for the ages. Every piece of music is outstanding, especially the last track of the movie. The pacing is immaculate because the opening sequence showcases that this isn't going to be a slow moving film which it isn't. There are slower moments but that's only to give the audience time to digest the characters and learn more about them and what's going on.

The story and characters really help this movie. First, we have Ashitaka. The young, pretty boy hero who wants both sides of the war to be in peace and tries to do that while maintaining his curse. San, the Princess Mononoke herself, also three dimensional. She's the Princess of the forest gods and is the love interest for Ashitaka since even though she lives with animals, she's still a human. Lady Eboshi may come off as an antagonist but really isn't because there's no villain character in the film making the world feel more alive and the characters more realistic despite that some of them are giant talking animals.

Remember the environmental message I talked about? Well, I always thought this was the true message of the film: Throughout the movie, Ashitaka and San grow closer and than right before the movie ends, they confess their feelings for one another. This highlights something: love the unloved, love the sacred and forgotten, and love people enough that they understand you love them without staying with them. They don't even kiss once throughout the entire film because Miyazaki is smart enough to showcase their love without something cliched like that.

Overall, Hayao Miyazaki's Princess Mononoke is one of the best films I've ever seen. It's a film that I can put on at any point and still love it the same way. I've seen it countless times and it never gets old. 100% recommend.

title: Epic is the purest word to describe this movie !
review: First Studio Ghibli movie to mix hand-drawn and CG-animation, resulting in a piece of art and the greatest Studio Ghibli film ever created. A masterwork with compelling characters, a fascinating story and a great message to be learned. Hayao Miyazaki's best film still manages to put many modern anime movies to shame with its amazing visuals, action packed scenes and wonderful soundtrack by Joe Hisaishi. Mononoke Hime avoids the classic black or white morality issue and deals with more powerful themes than other Ghibli movies, turning this film from something that could've easily been a children's book into a fantastic tale for people of all ages. This is, in my opinion, the best anime film of all time.

title: Yesterday Vibes
review: Feels like yesterday when I've watched that, still remember it. Miss those days

title: Another ghibli masterpiece!
review: So,my first impression of this movie was"wow this is violent". You know,having seen "Howl's moving castle","my neighbour totoro" and "spirited away" beforehand made it seem intense. but you know that's the only way they would've been able to illustrate how senseless human atrocities are. The first time I saw it,I didn't make much of it,but it kept playing in the background of my mind. And that's where the genius of it lies,in my opinion. I mean,any movie that keeps you thinking afterwards is a successful movie. My takeaway from it was,other than the obvious "humans,stop messing with mother nature",it was most importantly the terribleness -if I may - of hatred and anger. What I learned from it is that when people feel hurt,they can become toxic if they choose not to forgive and hold on to their grudges. Like, that boar literally turned to a demon and was infecting whoever came close to him because he let hate get the best of him. Also,it made me realize that,indeed,like the movie pointed out,hate does feed on anger and fear. Also,it highlights the idea that each story has two sides,and we should really drop our prejudices in order to make room for understanding. All in all,this movie is a piece of art that you don't have to understand or appreciate from the first time,but that gets many messages through.

review: Play Mononoke-hime! It is fast and easy to view! A good way to spend your time. Be the best!
